ABSTRACT: In total, 170 corn fields were surveyed in Ontario during the 2022 crop season. The frequencies of detected leaf diseases were anthracnose leaf blight (ALB) 141 (83%), northern corn leaf blight (NCLB) 129 (76%), common rust (CR) 78 (46%), tar spot (TS) 70 (41%), grey leaf spot (GLS) 68 (40%), Physoderma brown spot (PBS) 68 (40%), eyespot 63 (37%), and northern corn leaf spot (NCLS) 37 (22%). Mean severities of 1.8±1.1, 1.5±0.4, 1.4±0.7, 1.4±0.6, 1.2±0.4, 1.2±0.4, 1.2±0.4, and 1.2±0.2 were recorded for NCLB, ALB, TS, CR, eyespot, GLS, NCLS, and PBS, respectively. NCLB caused the most damage with severities ≥ 5 across Ontario and extremely severe disease in Elgin County, along Lake Erie. All 41 hybrids (fields) with NCLB resistant genes showed a resistant lesion-type and had a severity ≤2. Some genotypes had severities ≥4 for TS, CR, GLS and NLS in Ontario Corn Committee trials or seed company demonstration plots. There were 44 (26%) fields with common smut, but only three fields with incidences of 2%, 5%, and 12%; others were <1%. One field was found with low levels of head smut <1%. Ear rot was found in eight fields with incidence <1% which supports the annual OMAFRA Corn Ear Survey. Anthracnose top dieback (ATDB) was found in 141 (83%) of surveyed fields, ranging from 5 - 100%. Stalk rots, including pythium stalk rot and fusarium stalk rot, were found in 44 (26%) fields, 10 of them ranging from 5 – 65%, others <1%. Stewart’s bacterial wilt and Goss’s bacterial wilt were not detected; however, the corn flea beetle, the vector of Stewart’s bacterial wilt was found at one location in Chatham-Kent County.

INTRODUCTION AND METHODS: The annual corn disease survey provides vital information on populations of endemic pathogens and quarantine diseases, such as Goss’s bacterial wilt and blight (Clavibacter michiganensis subsp. nebraskensis) and Stewart’s bacterial wilt (Pantoea stewartii), and allows for scouting of new invasive pathogens like tar spot of corn [Phyllachora maydis Maubl.]. To document the occurrence of various corn diseases across the province, a survey was conducted from September 12th to 16th in Eastern Ontario and September 19th to 24th in Southern and Central Ontario, 2022. The 170 corn fields surveyed, based on GPS coordinates (latitude and longitude), are presented in . Because of severe drought and early harvest in Central and Southern Ontario, fewer seed corn fields in Chatham-Kent and grain/silage corn fields in Waterloo and Wellington counties were surveyed. The diseases surveyed included anthracnose leaf blight (ALB) (Colletotrichum graminicola (Ces.) G.W. Wilson); eyespot [Aureobasidium zeae (Narita & Hiratsuka) Dingley]; grey leaf spot (GLS) (Cercospora zeae-maydis Tehon & E.Y. Daniels); northern corn leaf blight (NCLB) [Exserohilum turcicum (Pass.) K.J. Leonard and E.G. Suggs]; northern corn leaf spot (NCLS) [Bipolaris zeicola (G.L. Stout) Shoemaker]; common rust (CR) (Puccinia sorghi Schwein.); southern rust (P. polyspora Underw.); tar spot, Physoderma brown spot [Physoderma maydis Miyabe (Miyabe)]; common smut [Ustilago maydis (DC.) Corda]; head smut [Sphacelotheca reiliana (Kuhn) G.P. Clinton]; ear rot (Fusarium spp.), stalk rot and anthracnose top dieback (ATDB) (Fusarium spp., Pythium spp., and C. graminicola); Goss’s bacterial wilt and blight, and Stewart’s bacterial wilt.

A rating scale of 1 to 7 based on percent area diseased, where 1 = no disease and 7 = severely diseased, was used for recording disease severity (Reid and Zhu Citation2005). Disease incidence was estimated based on the number of plants with a particular disease symptom for smut, ear rot, and stalk rot. Leaf samples showing typical NCLB symptoms (long, elliptical, 2-15 cm, tan or greyish-green, necrotic lesions) were collected from each field visited for E. turcicum race identification and distribution patterns. Additional symptomatic plant parts were also collected for subsequent laboratory analysis, especially for unknown or suspected Goss’s bacterial wilt, Stewart’s bacterial wilt, and bacterial leaf streak (Xanthomonas vasicola Cobb).

RESULTS AND COMMENTS:

Northern corn leaf blight (NCLB) was the most common foliar disease in 2022. NCLB was detected in all counties () and in 129 of the 170 surveyed fields, with 7, 60 and 103 fields infected in Central, Eastern and Western Ontario, respectively. shows that fields with severity ≥5 (labeled with a blue circle with a big white center), were scattered throughout Central, Western and Eastern Ontario. There was a wider diseased area in Elgin County, along Lake Erie. In southwestern St. Thomas, >10 km of corn fields along the Lake Erie shoreline had NCLB severity >5, with up to 50-75% diseased leaf areas. NCLB was found in 15 of the 16 OCC 2022 performance trials (), of which two locations (Ridgetown and Wingham) had hybrids with higher severity ratings (≥4). Based on NCLB lesion size, colour and position on the plants, NCLB likely started late in the 2022 growing season, in early September in Eastern Ontario and late August in Southern and Central Ontario. All 41 of 129 (32%) NCLB fields with resistant lesions (genes) had severity <2, even in the area with the most severe disease epidemic. Commercial hybrids with NCLB resistant gene(s) should be used in the historic NCLB epidemic areas, such as corn fields near Lake Huron, Lake Erie and Lake Ontario.

Tar spot is a recent corn disease, detected for the first time in the United States in Illinois and Indiana in 2015. In 2018, tar spot was detected in Michigan, southern Wisconsin, Ohio, eastern Iowa and Florida (Dalla et al. Citation2019), and in Canada, it was reported late in the 2020 growing season (Tenuta Citation2020). There was a tar spot outbreak in Southern Ontario in 2021 (Hein Citation2022). Although new, tar spot was the second most damaging foliar disease in the survey with an average severity of 1.4±0.7, mainly distributed in eight Southern Ontario counties: Chatham-Kent, Elgin, Essex, Huron, Lambton, Middlesex, Norfolk, and Oxford (). There were 10 fields with severities ranging from 4 to 5, located in Chatham-Kent, Elgin, Huron, and Middlesex (). Of the 10 fields, three were in Elgin and had both severe NCLB and tar spot. Tar spot was found in six out of the 16 OCC 2022 performance trials (), of which two locations (Dresden and Tilbury) had hybrids with higher severity ratings (≥3).

Tar spot symptoms appeared on the whole plant (severity ≥4), bottom leaves (severity ≥3), or a single leaf at the bottom or middle of the plant. Hundreds of stroma could be found on one leaf, while other leaves on the same plant were clean. In a very short time, tar spot has become established and overwinters in southwestern Ontario. This local overwintering source, as well as potential air-borne inoculum from the U. S. Midwest (especially Ohio, Indiana, Michigan and Wisconsin), and historical end of season maps showing the spread of tar spot in the U. S. from 2015 to 2022 (https://corn.ipmpipe.org/tarspot/historical-end-of-season-maps/), suggest that tar spot will have an annual impact in the province of Ontario.

Anthracnose leaf blight (ALB) was the most common foliar disease, found in 141 (83%) of surveyed corn fields with an average severity of 1.5±0.4 in all Ontario counties in 2022 (). Heavier ALB (≥4) was found on a few hybrids in two Winchester OCC trials () and one field corn in Elgin County.

Common rust (CR) was detected in 78 (46%) of surveyed fields with an average severity of 1.4±0.6 across Ontario; 86% of surveyed fields had an average severity of 2.4±0.6, 60% of fields had an average severity of 1.5±0.8, and 35% fields an average severity of 1.2±0.4, in Central, Eastern, and Southern Ontario, respectively (). Heavier CR (≥4) was found on some hybrids in Bainsville and Waterloo OCC trials (). One sweet corn variety in Carleton-Ottawa County and one ornamental (flint) corn variety in Wellington County were very susceptible to CR (≥5).

Southern rust was not detected in 2022.

Grey leaf spot (GLS) was found in 68 (40%) of the fields sampled with an average severity of 1.2±0.4 (). Of the 68 GLS fields, 64 fields were in Southern Ontario, with only two in Central and two in Eastern Ontario. Compared to previous years in Southern Ontario (Jindal et al. Citation2017, Citation2018, Citation2019), GLS was less common and a minor disease in 2022. Only a few hybrids in the Ilderton and Ridgetown OCC trials showed a severity of 4, and one field corn in Elgin County had a severity of 3.5. Compared to 2021 (Zhu et al. Citation2022), the frequency of GLS was also lower in Eastern Ontario during the 2022 growing season.

Northern corn leaf spot (NCLS) was found in 37 (22%) of 170 surveyed fields across Ontario with an average severity of 1.2±0.4 (). All symptoms in 2022 resembled race 3 of NCLS, which is easily confused with bacterial leaf streak. Both diseases form long, narrow, linear strips (spots) along small leaf veins. However, race 3 of NCLS has more yellowish strips that sometimes cross two or more small veins (White Citation2001). Conidiophores and/or spores of NCLS can be seen under the microscope. Of 37 NCLS fields, 31 were in Central and Southern Ontario, with the exception of Essex and Lambton counties where none were found in 2022. Some hybrids in Blyth and Wingham OCC trials had a severity of up to 4 (). Severe NCLS appeared with ALB or NCLB and tar spot in two field corn fields in Elgin, with 100% incidence and a severity of 3 to 4. NCLS has become more common across the province in recent years, as observed during our 1999 to 2022 annual corn disease surveys.

Eyespot was less prevalent in 2022, which is similar to previous years (Jindal et al. Citation2017, Citation2018, Citation2019; Zhu et al. Citation2022). This disease was found in 63 (37%) of the surveyed fields with an average severity of 1.2±0.4 (). Eyespot was found more frequently in Central (5/7) and Eastern (29/60) than in Southern (29/103) Ontario. Four grain corn fields with eyespot severity ranging from 2.5 to 3.5 were found in Huron, Wellington, and Carleton-Ottawa counties. Other fields, including all OCC trials, had low severity (<2) ().

Other leaf diseases: Physoderma brown spot was found in 68 (40%) of fields with an average severity of 1.2±0.2. All symptoms appeared on leaf sheaths with low severity <2. Phaeosphaeria leaf spot, caused by Phaeosphaeria maydis, was found once in Winchester OCC trials.

Holcus leaf spot, Stewart’s bacterial wilt, and Goss’s bacterial wilt and blight were not found in Ontario in 2022.

Fungal ear and stalk rot diseases:

Common smut was found in 44 (26%) of sampled fields with an average incidence of 0.4±1.2 (). The symptoms were mostly observed on ears or lower nodes of the plant. In the Carleton-Ottawa area, inbred lines in two isolation blocks had incidences 5% and 12%. All grain fields, and six of 16 OCC trials had incidence <1% (). Head smut was found in one field in Essex County in 2022 with incidence <1%. Ear rot, with an average incidence of 0.0±0.2, was found in eight (5%) of the sampled fields. All had low incidence (<1%).

Anthracnose top dieback (ATDB), caused by C. graminicola, was very common, found in 141 (83%) of sampled fields with an average incidence of 16.7±15.6 (). Higher incidences were found in early planted fields, early maturity hybrids, and fields which were impacted by drought. Of the 141 ATDB fields, 11 fields had an incidence <10%, 120 fields had incidence of 10-25%, seven fields had an incidence of 50%, and three fields had an incidence of 75-100%.

Stalk rots: The most common symptoms were attributed to pythium stalk rot with a few fusarium stalk rot. Stalk rots were found in 44 (26%) fields with an average incidence of 1.7±7.3 (). Six isolation blocks in Carleton-Ottawa and two seed corn fields in Chatham-Kent counties, had an incidence ranging from 11-25%. Hybrids in Waterloo OCC trials had an incidence of stalk rot ranging from 20-80% and Wingham OCC ranged from 30-90% (). Heavier pythium stalk rot was the result of heavy rains in the middle of September after an extended dry period which occurred during corn maturing stages of development. Fusarium stalk rot was at low levels during the 2022 survey period.

Others: Corn rootworms, either northern corn rootworm [Diabrotica longicornis (Say)] or western corn rootworm (D. virgifera); Grasshoppers (Melanoplus spp.), European corn borer [Ostrinia nubilalis (Hübner)], leaf miner (Agramyza parvicornis Loew), corn aphids [Rhopalosiphum maidis (Fitch)] were found in 96 (57%), 122 (72%), 30 (18%), 14 (8%), and 6 (4%) of fields, respectively. Spider mite (Tetranychus urticae Koch = T. bimaculatus Harvey) was found in 64 (38%) of fields. Twenty-three fields had bird damage and one field had large animal damage. Eight fields had hail damage. Sixteen fields showed significant drought problems with stunted plants and dry ears. Corn flea beetle (Chaetocnema pulicaria M.), the vector of Stewart’s wilt, was found in one field in Chatham-Kent in 2022.
